Modified-Alt-Text: Scatter plot titled “Train Motion.” The x-axis is time (min) from 0 to 70, and the y-axis is distance from station (km) from 0 to 160. Red data points show distance increasing over time.

Scatter plot titled “Train Motion” with red data points and a straight red trend line drawn upward from left to right. The x-axis is time (min) and the y-axis is distance from station (km). The line can be used to estimate slope (rate of change) and the y-intercept where it crosses the y-axis.

Four example graphs showing common relationships: linear (straight line), quadratic (curved parabola), inverse (decreasing curve that levels off), and exponential (rapidly increasing or decreasing curve). Use the shapes to match a dataset to a relationship type.

Two-panel figure showing logarithmic scales. (a) “Richter Scale: A Graphic Representation.” The x-axis is earthquake magnitude (about −1 to 9) and the y-axis is amplified maximum ground motion in microns on a base-10 log scale (about 10^−1 to 10^9). A red curve rises sharply: very small magnitudes near 0–2 are labeled “Not felt,” around 4 is “Minor,” 5 “Small,” 6 “Moderate,” 7 “Strong,” 8 “Major,” and near 9 “Great.” (b) Log–log plot of frequency (s^−1) versus wavelength (cm), with red points lying on a straight downward-sloping red line, showing frequency decreasing as wavelength increases.

Line graph of water temperature over time. Temperature rises from near room temperature to about boiling, then levels off near the boiling temperature. Use the y-intercept to read the starting temperature and the slope to see how quickly temperature changes.

East–west number line with sign convention (east positive, west negative). A displacement of −3 km points west from the start, then a displacement of +2 km points east. Add the signed displacements to find the net change from initial to final position.

Round trip diagram from Home to Store and back. The two path arrows show equal distances in opposite directions (total distance is the sum of both legs). A separate note indicates the start and end are the same location, so net displacement is zero.

Segmented motion diagram along one axis. Multiple displacement vectors (Δd_a, Δd_b, Δd_c, Δd_d) show parts of a trip in different directions. A final vector Δd_total shows the overall displacement from the initial position d0 to the final position df (vector sum of segments).

Diagram explaining y = mx + b. A straight line crosses the y-axis at b (y-intercept). A rise/run triangle shows slope m as Δy/Δx. Use rise and run to calculate the slope and use the axis crossing to identify the intercept.

Position vs time graph for a vehicle moving at constant speed. A straight line is labeled in the form d = d0 + vt. The y-intercept marks the initial position d0, and a slope triangle shows v = Δd/Δt using two points on the line.

Position vs time graph where the curve becomes steeper over time (speeding up). Two points on the curve are marked, each with a small tangent-slope triangle. Compare the triangles to see that instantaneous velocity (slope) is larger at the later point.

Position vs time graph with data points connected by a slightly upward-curving line. The slope increases gradually, indicating velocity increases over time. Estimate velocity at a time by finding the local slope of the curve.

Position vs time graph with points forming an increasing curve that becomes steeper. The increasing steepness indicates increasing velocity. Use the slope at a chosen time to estimate instantaneous velocity.

Position vs time graph for a trip away from home and back. The line rises to a maximum position (farthest point) then falls back to zero position. Positive slope indicates moving away; negative slope indicates returning.

Velocity vs time graph for the same round trip. A horizontal segment at positive velocity indicates constant speed away from home, then the graph jumps to a horizontal segment at negative velocity for constant speed back. Use the sign to determine direction.

Position vs time curve that steepens with time, showing increasing velocity. Two points on the curve have slope triangles; the later triangle is steeper, indicating a larger instantaneous velocity later.

Velocity vs time graph with a straight rising line, showing velocity increases linearly with time. The constant slope represents constant acceleration. Pick any two points on the line to compute acceleration as Δv/Δt.

Velocity vs. time graph titled “Jet Car Velocity.” The green curve starts near 165 m/s at t = 0 s, rises quickly, then levels off near 250 m/s by about 50–70 s. A black line is drawn as an approximate tangent/line of best fit, overlapping the green curve most closely around t ≈ 25–35 s (v ≈ 235–245 m/s). A slope box is drawn with Δt along the horizontal and Δv along the vertical, and the top-right corner is near t ≈ 50 s and v ≈ 260 m/s.
Velocity vs time graph that rises from zero to a constant value, stays flat, then decreases back to zero. Net displacement is the total area under the curve (triangle + rectangle + triangle).

Position vs time graph for a runner. The line rises (moving forward) then becomes horizontal (stopped). Use the slope to determine velocity: positive on the rising segment and zero on the flat segment.

Qualitative velocity–time sketch on axes labeled v (vertical) and t (horizontal). The graph begins with a horizontal segment at positive velocity, then drops with a steep downward slope, followed by a longer section with a gentler downward slope until it reaches v = 0 on the time axis.

Position vs time curve labeled with points. The curve rises but gradually flattens, meaning the object keeps moving forward while slowing down. Instantaneous velocity corresponds to slope at each point.

Position vs time curve with several peaks and valleys labeled. Slope is positive where the curve rises and negative where it falls; slope is zero at local maxima and minima. Use steepness to compare instantaneous speeds at different points.

Position vs time graph for a runner that rises then stays flat. The motion includes a forward move followed by a stop. Use the overall change in position divided by total time to compute average velocity.

Velocity vs time graph that increases quickly then levels off. The curve’s decreasing steepness shows acceleration is positive but getting smaller over time. Instantaneous acceleration is the slope at a point.
Position vs time graph for a runner that rises then stays flat. Use the slope of the rising segment to estimate velocity during motion and the flat segment to identify when velocity is zero.
Position vs time graph with points forming a curve that becomes steeper. Increasing steepness indicates increasing velocity. Use the slope at a chosen time to estimate instantaneous velocity.
Velocity vs time graph with a straight rising line. Velocity increases at a constant rate, so acceleration is constant. Compute acceleration from the slope Δv/Δt.

Velocity vs time graph with a straight rising line, indicating constant acceleration. Average acceleration can be found from slope, and displacement over an interval can be estimated from area under the line.

One-dimensional motion paths on an x-axis. Multiple colored paths show different routes between start and end positions. Use start and end to find displacement (xf − xi) and use the full traced route length to compare total distance traveled.
Position vs time graph with a curve that becomes steeper over time. The increasing slope indicates the object’s velocity is increasing (accelerating).
Position vs time graph with segments of rising, falling, and flat motion. Positive slope means moving forward, negative slope means moving backward, and flat segments mean stopped.

Qualitative velocity vs time graph labeled with points. Velocity increases and decreases over time; upward slopes indicate positive acceleration and downward slopes indicate negative acceleration. Steeper sections indicate larger acceleration magnitude.
Position vs time graph that rises, then falls, then rises steeply. Use the sign of slope to identify direction of motion (positive forward, negative backward) and compare steepness to compare speed.
Displacement vs time graph shown as a straight line rising from left to right. A constant slope indicates constant velocity. Use the slope of the line to determine velocity.
Velocity vs time graph shown as a straight line rising from left to right. A constant slope indicates constant acceleration. Use the slope Δv/Δt to compute acceleration.
Graph of 2d versus t squared drawn as a straight line through the origin. For constant acceleration starting from rest, the slope of the 2d vs t^2 line equals the acceleration.

Graph with v squared on the vertical axis and 2d on the horizontal axis, showing a straight rising line. The figure emphasizes choosing variables so a relationship becomes linear, allowing the unknown to be found from slope and intercept.

Initial-condition diagram for vertical motion. An arrow upward indicates initial velocity v0, and an arrow downward indicates constant acceleration a = −g. Use the directions and values as knowns before solving for position or velocity at later times.

Three stacked graphs for an object thrown straight up and coming down: position vs time is a curved arch (up then down), velocity vs time is a straight line decreasing through zero, and acceleration vs time is a horizontal line below zero. Use slope and area ideas to connect the graphs.

Hanging mass on a rope with force arrows. Tension T points upward and weight w (mg) points downward; a matching free-body diagram shows the same forces on a dot. Use arrows to represent force direction and relative size.

Box sliding right on a horizontal surface. Velocity arrow points right; friction f points left along the surface. Normal force FN points up and weight mg points down. A small free-body diagram repeats the forces to show friction opposes motion.
Person pushing a lawn mower with a net force arrow pointing to the right. Use the net-force direction to determine the direction of the acceleration.

Hand holding a vertical rope attached to a hanging mass. Tension forces act along the rope: the rope pulls upward on the mass and downward on the hand with equal magnitude. A separate weight arrow on the mass points downward.

Vector addition by head-to-tail method. One vector points east and a second points north from the first vector’s head. A diagonal resultant is drawn from the starting point to the final point; a right triangle shows the components and the angle of the resultant.

Resultant vector on x–y axes with a labeled magnitude and an angle above the +x direction. Images of a ruler and a protractor indicate measuring vector length for magnitude and measuring the angle from the reference axis for direction.

Head-to-tail vector diagram with a resultant R drawn from the origin to the final point and labeled with magnitude and a small angle below the +x axis. Instruction is to measure R’s length using the scale and measure its direction as an angle from a reference axis.

Two vectors on coordinate axes with labeled magnitudes and direction angles. Use the arrows to represent each leg of motion and use the angles (measured from the reference axis) to describe direction.

Graphical vector addition/subtraction path on x–y axes with connected arrows and a resultant R from start to end. Use head-to-tail placement to combine vectors, then read the resultant’s magnitude and direction.

Single vector labeled −B on x–y axes showing the same length as B but pointing opposite. Angle markings indicate the reversed direction. Use −B to represent traveling in the opposite direction of vector B.

Triangle diagram showing subtraction as addition: A and −B are placed head-to-tail and the resultant R is drawn from the start of A to the end of −B. Measure R to report the magnitude and direction of A − B.

Velocity vectors for river crossing. One vector represents boat velocity through water and another represents river current; the total velocity is the diagonal resultant. Use head-to-tail addition (or a right triangle) to find the resultant speed and its direction angle.

Right triangle labeled with adjacent side x, opposite side y, and hypotenuse h, with angle θ. Trig definitions are shown: sin θ = y/h, cos θ = x/h, tan θ = y/x. Use these ratios to relate components to the hypotenuse and angle.

Vector components diagram. A vector A at angle θ is drawn from the origin; dashed lines form a right triangle to the axes. Horizontal component is labeled Ax and vertical component is labeled Ay. Use projections onto axes to resolve A into perpendicular components.

Vector A is drawn from the origin at an angle θ above the +x axis. Dashed lines drop to the axes to form a right triangle, showing the components Ax along x and Ay along y. Labels indicate Ax = A cos(θ) and Ay = A sin(θ), illustrating that the x- and y-components add to represent the original vector.

Right-triangle diagram for a vector A and its components. Ax is the horizontal leg and Ay is the vertical leg, shown with dashed lines; the diagonal arrow is labeled A. The magnitude relation A = sqrt(Ax^2 + Ay^2) is written along the diagonal, and the direction is labeled θ = tan^-1(Ay/Ax).

Head-to-tail vector addition on x–y axes. Vector A starts at the origin; vector B starts at the head of A. The resultant R is drawn from the origin to the head of B and labeled A + B = R. Use this construction to add two vectors graphically.

Head-to-tail vector addition on x–y axes. Vector A (red) starts at the origin at angle θA, and vector B (blue) starts at the head of A at angle θB. The resultant R runs from the origin to the head of B and is labeled A + B = R. Dashed projections show components Ax and Ay for A, and Bx and By for B.

Vector addition on x–y axes with compass directions shown at left. Vector A (red) starts at the origin and vector B (blue) starts at the head of A; the resultant R (purple) runs from the origin to the head of B and is labeled A + B = R. Dashed projection lines show A’s components Ax (horizontal) and Ay (vertical) and B’s components Bx (horizontal) and By (vertical). The combined components are labeled Rx = Ax + Bx along the bottom and Ry = Ay + By along the left, and the angle θ of R is marked from the +x axis.

Vector addition diagram on x–y axes with compass directions at left. Vector A (red) is labeled A = 53.0 m at angle θA = 20.0° above the +x axis. Vector B (blue) starts at the head of A and is labeled B = 34.0 m at angle θB = 63.0°. The resultant R (black) runs from the origin to the head of B and is labeled A + B = R, with the resultant angle marked θ = 36.6°.

Projectile motion diagram on x–y axes. A kicked ball follows a curved red trajectory with several ball positions shown along the arc. A straight displacement vector d points from the launch point to the landing point at an angle θ above the horizontal. Dashed lines form a right triangle with horizontal leg labeled x and vertical leg labeled y.

A firework is launched from the bottom-left corner and travels in a curved arc to the upper right. A green arrow labeled v0 shows the launch direction, tilted steeply upward, and the launch angle is labeled θ0 = 75°. Dashed lines extend from the highest point of the arc to show the peak height h and the horizontal distance to that peak.

Weight components on an incline. The weight vector w points straight down and is resolved into two perpendicular components relative to the ramp: w parallel to the slope and w perpendicular to the slope. The diagram labels w∥ = w sin(θ) = mg sin(θ) and w⊥ = w cos(θ) = mg cos(θ), showing how gravity splits into along-slope and into-slope components.

Skier on a 25 degree incline with axes drawn parallel and perpendicular to the slope. Forces shown are weight w straight down, normal force N perpendicular to the surface, and friction f along the slope opposing motion. The weight vector is split into components w parallel (down the slope) and w perpendicular (into the slope) using a dashed right triangle. A simplified free body diagram repeats N, f, w, and the weight components.

Five panels (a–e) show a flexible ruler oscillating about the labeled equilibrium position. (a) The ruler is displaced left and a force arrow F points right toward equilibrium. (b) The ruler is at equilibrium with the label F = 0 and a velocity arrow v pointing to the right. (c) The ruler is displaced right and a force arrow F points left toward equilibrium. (d) The ruler is back at equilibrium with the label F = 0 and a velocity arrow v pointing to the left. (e) The ruler is displaced left again with a force arrow F pointing right.

Simple pendulum with bob of mass m on a string of length L displaced by angle theta from vertical. Forces are tension T along the string toward the pivot and weight w equals mg straight down. A dashed construction highlights the component of gravity along the arc, labeled minus mg sin theta, pointing toward equilibrium as the restoring force. The arc displacement from equilibrium is labeled s.

Two bodies with masses m and M are shown with their centers of mass marked CM and separated by distance r. Force arrows labeled F lie along the line connecting the centers and point toward each other. The diagram emphasizes that gravitational attraction acts along the center to center line and the forces on the two masses are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

Cavendish torsion balance: two small spheres m on a horizontal bar suspended by a thin fiber. Two larger spheres M are placed nearby to attract the small spheres, twisting the fiber about the pivot. A mirror reflects a light beam from a source onto a scale so the twist angle can be read from the movement of the light spot.

A distant star and the Sun are shown with a light path curving as it passes near the Sun toward an Earth-bound observer. The observer traces the arriving light back and sees the star at a shifted apparent position compared with the actual star location.

Left shows a hand using a pry bar to lift a nail, illustrating a lever. Right shows a lever with a fulcrum: resistance force Fr on one side and effort force Fe on the other, with arm lengths Lr and Le labeled. Ideal mechanical advantage is shown as Le divided by Lr.

Wheel-and-axle diagram with large radius R and smaller axle radius r. Effort force Fe is applied at the wheel rim, and a rope around the axle lifts a load with force Fr. The diagram shows ideal mechanical advantage increases with R/r.

Side-by-side diagrams of an inclined plane and a wedge. The inclined plane shows a block on a ramp with the ramp length L and height h labeled, and an arrow showing effort force up the slope; the formula IMA = L/h is written above. The wedge shows length L and thickness t labeled; the formula IMA = L/t is written above.

On the left, an inclined plane is shown lifting a block. The vertical height the load is raised is called the height (h). The distance along the surface of the ramp is called the length (L). A force is applied to the block parallel to the surface of the ramp to move it upward. The ideal mechanical advantage (IMA) of the inclined plane is defined as the length of the ramp divided by the vertical height, written as IMA = L divided by h. This shows that a longer ramp reduces the force needed to lift the object, at the cost of applying the force over a greater distance. On the right, a wedge is shown. The wedge has a length along its sloping surface called the length (L) and a thickness at the wide end called the thickness (t). The ideal mechanical advantage of the wedge is defined as the length divided by the thickness, written as IMA = L divided by t. A longer and thinner wedge provides a greater mechanical advantage by spreading the applied force over a larger distance. This figure demonstrates that simple machines increase force by increasing the distance over which the force is applied, which is a fundamental principle of mechanical advantage.

pulley systems and their ideal mechanical advantage (IMA). From left to right: a single fixed pulley (N = 1) where the effort force equals the load; a single movable pulley (N = 2) where two rope segments support the load; and a compound block-and-tackle system (N = 4) where four rope segments support the load, reducing the required effort force. Arrows show the direction of applied effort and load forces.

a lever used to pry a nail from wood. The left image shows a hand applying effort to a pry bar lifting a nail. The right schematic labels the fulcrum, effort force (Fe), resistance force (Fr), effort arm length (Le), and resistance arm length (Lr), with the ideal mechanical advantage given by IMA = Le / Lr.

an inclined plane and a wedge. On the left, a block is pushed up an inclined plane of length L and height h, with effort force Fe applied; the ideal mechanical advantage is shown as IMA = L / h. On the right, a wedge with length L and thickness t is labeled, with its ideal mechanical advantage given by IMA = L / t.

a wheel-and-axle simple machine. A large wheel of radius R is connected to a smaller axle of radius r. An effort force (Fe) is applied at the edge of the wheel, while a load force (Fr) acts on the axle via a rope. The ideal mechanical advantage is labeled as IMA = R / r.

An astronaut uses an electronic timer to measure the time for a light pulse to travel from a source to a mirror and back inside her spacecraft. In the astronaut’s frame, the light moves straight up and down over a fixed distance. An observer on Earth sees the spacecraft moving, so the light follows a longer diagonal path and takes more time. This illustrates time dilation, where the observed time Δt is greater than the proper time Δt₀ by the relativistic factor γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²).

Relativistic momentum versus speed graph showing p_rel on the vertical axis and speed u as a fraction of the speed of light c on the horizontal axis. Momentum increases slowly at low speeds, closely matching classical momentum, then rises sharply as u approaches c. A dashed vertical line at u = c indicates that the speed of light cannot be reached. The graph illustrates that relativistic momentum increases without bound as velocity approaches the speed of light, ensuring momentum conservation in all inertial reference frames and preventing massive objects from reaching or exceeding c.

Natural convection heating system inside a house. A gravity furnace heats air near the floor, causing the warm air to rise and circulate along the ceiling. As the air cools near the walls and windows, it becomes denser and sinks back down toward the floor. Blue arrows indicate cooler, sinking air, and red arrows indicate warmer, rising air. This continuous circulation shows convection driven by temperature differences and density changes in air.

Comparison of particle motion in different states of matter. (a) Solid: particles are closely packed in a fixed lattice and vibrate about equilibrium positions. (b) Liquid: particles are close together but move randomly and slide past one another. (c) Gas: particles are far apart and move rapidly in random directions, shown by long arrows. (d) Plasma: positively charged ions and free electrons move independently at high speeds, illustrated by charged particles within a cloud.

A heating curve showing temperature versus added energy for water. The vertical axis shows temperature in degrees Celsius, and the horizontal axis shows added heat per unit mass (ΔQ/m). Ice warms from below 0°C to 0°C, then temperature remains constant at 0°C while ice melts into liquid water, illustrating the latent heat of fusion. The temperature of liquid water then rises to 100°C, followed by another flat region at 100°C where water and steam coexist during vaporization, representing the latent heat of vaporization. After all liquid has vaporized, the temperature of steam increases with additional energy.

Figure illustrating how pressure in a tire changes with added air and temperature. (a) When air is first pumped into a deflated tire, the volume increases significantly with little change in pressure. (b) As more air is added, the tire walls resist further expansion, so the pressure increases as additional air is pumped in. (c) Once the tire is fully inflated and volume is nearly constant, increasing the temperature of the air inside the tire causes the pressure to rise.

Expansion of a gas in a piston–cylinder system. A gas at pressure P pushes a piston of cross-sectional area A upward by a distance d, increasing the volume by ΔV = A·d. The upward force on the piston is F = P·A, and heat Q_in is added to the gas to maintain constant pressure during expansion. The diagram shows that the work done by the gas on the piston is W_out = F·d = P·A·d = P·ΔV, illustrating pressure–volume work for a constant-pressure process.

the first law of thermodynamics for a system. Heat Q enters or leaves the system, and work W is done by or on the system. The change in internal energy is shown as ΔU = Q − W, where Q represents the net heat transfer into the system and W represents the net work done by the system. Arrows indicate heat flowing into and out of the system (Q_in and Q_out) and work done by the system (W_out) or on the system (W_in), emphasizing energy conservation through heat and work transfers.

the first law of thermodynamics to biological systems. (a) A human body is shown as a system where food energy enters, increasing internal energy, while heat Q is transferred out and work W is done by the body, reducing internal energy. The relationship is expressed as ΔU = Q − W + food energy, illustrating metabolism as an energy balance. (b) A plant receives energy from the Sun as heat input Q_in, stores part of this energy as chemical (food) energy, and releases some energy as heat Q_out, showing how plants convert solar energy into stored internal energy.

Two energy-flow diagrams showing that different processes can result in the same change in internal energy. In (a), 15 J of net heat enters the system while 6 J of net work is done by the system, giving a change in internal energy of ΔU = Q − W = 9 J. In (b), 150 J of heat leaves the system while 159 J of work is done on the system, also producing ΔU = 9 J. The diagrams illustrate that if a system starts in the same initial state, different combinations of heat transfer and work can lead to the same final state and the same change in internal energy.

Examples of one-way (irreversible) processes in nature. (a) Heat flows spontaneously from a hot region to a cold region, shown by heat Q moving from hot to cold, but the reverse does not occur without external work. (b) A moving car slows to rest as its brakes convert kinetic energy into internal energy, which is then transferred as heat to the surroundings; the reverse process does not happen spontaneously. (c) A puff of gas released into a vacuum rapidly spreads out to form a uniform distribution, and the random motion of gas molecules prevents the gas from spontaneously re-collecting into one region.

Ice-to-water entropy increase diagram. On the left, ice is shown as an ordered structure with molecules arranged in a regular lattice. An arrow labeled ΔS > 0 points to the right, where liquid water is shown with molecules moving randomly in many directions. The diagram illustrates that when ice melts into water, molecular order decreases, disorder increases, and entropy increases due to heat transfer into the system.

Gas–piston system illustrating energy transfer and work. (a) Heat Q_in is added to a gas in a cylinder, increasing its internal energy ΔU and raising pressure, which produces a force F = P·A on the piston. (b) The gas expands, pushing the piston outward by a distance d and doing work W_out = F·d; during expansion, the gas’s internal energy decreases. (c) Heat Q_out is transferred from the gas to the surroundings, further lowering pressure so a smaller opposing force F′ is needed to move the piston back inward, with work W_in = F′·d.

Heat transfer and heat engine diagrams used in thermodynamics to illustrate the second law of thermodynamics and the basic operation of heat engines. (a) Heat flows spontaneously from a hot reservoir at temperature T_h to a cold reservoir at temperature T_c. (b) A heat engine operates between these reservoirs, absorbing heat Q_h from the hot reservoir, converting part of it into useful work W, and releasing the remaining heat Q_c to the cold reservoir, with W = Q_h − Q_c. The diagram provides a conceptual framework for understanding energy conversion limits and efficiency in real engines.

a simple heat pump system used for heating buildings. The cycle includes four main components: (1) an evaporator outside the building, where the working fluid absorbs heat Q_c from the colder outdoor air and evaporates; (2) a compressor that increases the pressure and temperature of the vapor; (3) a condenser inside the building, where heat Q_h is released to the indoor space as the fluid condenses; and (4) an expansion valve that lowers the pressure and temperature of the fluid before it returns to the evaporator. The diagram illustrates how a heat pump transfers thermal energy from a cold outdoor environment to a warmer indoor space using mechanical work.

Heat pump (reversed heat engine) diagram illustrating how refrigerators and air conditioners operate. The system absorbs heat Q_c from a cold reservoir at temperature T_c and, with the input of external work W, transfers a larger amount of heat Q_h to a hot reservoir at temperature T_h. Arrows show heat being pumped from cold to hot against the natural direction of heat flow. The diagram provides an academic illustration of the second law of thermodynamics applied to cooling devices, emphasizing that work is required to move heat from a cooler region to a warmer one.

Transverse wave on a toy spring. A person moves her hand up and down, creating a vertical disturbance in the spring while the wave travels horizontally to the right. Arrows indicate the direction of wave propagation, showing that particle motion is perpendicular to the direction of energy transfer. This academic diagram contrasts transverse waves with longitudinal waves, where the disturbance is parallel to the direction of propagation.

Longitudinal wave on a toy spring. A person pushes and pulls the spring horizontally, creating regions of compression and rarefaction that move to the right. The arrows show the direction of wave propagation v_w, which is the same as the direction of particle motion. This academic diagram illustrates a longitudinal (compressional) wave, where the disturbance is parallel to the direction of energy transfer.

Comparison of transverse and longitudinal waves using sound and strings. A guitar string vibrates up and down, demonstrating a transverse wave where the string’s motion is perpendicular to the direction of wave travel. An amplifier and speaker produce sound waves that travel outward through the air as longitudinal waves, shown by compressions and rarefactions. A sheet of paper and a handheld tuning fork vibrate back and forth in the same direction as the sound propagation, illustrating that sound waves in air are longitudinal, while waves in solids and water can have both transverse and longitudinal components.

Water wave diagram illustrating key wave properties. The horizontal distance between successive crests is labeled as the wavelength λ. The vertical distance from the equilibrium (dashed) line to a crest or trough is the amplitude X, with a total peak-to-trough height of 2X. The wave propagates horizontally along the water surface at speed v_w, while individual water particles move up and down rather than traveling with the wave.

Speaker diagram illustrating the relationship between frequency and wavelength for sound waves. The small speaker (tweeter) produces high-frequency sound with a short wavelength λ, shown by closely spaced wavefronts. The large speaker (woofer) produces low-frequency sound with a longer wavelength, shown by widely spaced wavefronts. The diagram emphasizes that in a given medium where wave speed is constant, higher frequency corresponds to shorter wavelength and lower frequency corresponds to longer wavelength.

Constructive interference of waves diagram. Two identical waves (Wave 1 and Wave 2), each with amplitude X and the same wavelength, are shown aligned in phase so that their crests and troughs occur at the same positions. When the waves overlap, their displacements add, producing a resultant wave with twice the amplitude (2X) and the same wavelength. The diagram illustrates pure constructive interference, where wave amplitudes combine to increase the overall displacement without changing the wavelength.

Destructive interference of waves diagram. Two identical waves (Wave 1 and Wave 2) with the same wavelength and amplitude X are shown exactly out of phase, so the crest of one wave aligns with the trough of the other. When the waves overlap, their displacements cancel at every point, producing a resultant wave with zero amplitude. The diagram illustrates pure destructive interference, where complete cancellation occurs due to opposite displacements.

Superposition of nonidentical waves diagram. Wave 1 and Wave 2 have different wavelengths and amplitudes and overlap in the same region of space. When combined, the resulting wave shows a complex pattern with some regions of increased amplitude (constructive interference) and other regions of reduced amplitude (destructive interference). The diagram illustrates that most real wave interactions produce mixed interference rather than pure constructive or pure destructive cancellation.

Standing wave formation diagram. Two identical waves (Wave 1 and Wave 2) travel in opposite directions and overlap. Their superposition produces a standing wave (Resultant) with fixed points called nodes, where the displacement is always zero, and antinodes, where the displacement is maximum. The pattern does not travel through space but oscillates in place due to alternating constructive and destructive interference at specific locations.

Standing wave on a string diagram. A string fixed at both ends oscillates in its fundamental mode, forming a single loop between the supports. The ends are nodes, where the displacement is zero, and the center of the string is an antinode, where the displacement is maximum. The length of the string L corresponds to half a wavelength, labeled λ₁, illustrating the relationship between string length, wavelength, nodes, and antinodes in standing waves.

Higher harmonics of a standing wave on a string. Two examples show a string fixed at both ends oscillating with multiple loops. Nodes are points along the string that remain stationary, while loops (antinodes) are regions of maximum displacement. In the second harmonic (left), the string contains two loops and an additional node, with wavelength λ₂ related to the string length L. In the third harmonic (right), the string contains three loops and more nodes, with a shorter wavelength λ₃. The diagram illustrates how increasing the number of nodes corresponds to higher harmonics and shorter wavelengths in standing waves.

Reflection of a wave pulse from a fixed end. An incident pulse travels along a string toward a rigid, fixed boundary. Upon reaching the fixed end, the pulse reflects and becomes inverted, meaning the crest turns into a trough as it travels back in the opposite direction. The diagram illustrates that reflection at a fixed end causes a phase inversion, whereas reflection at a free end would not invert the pulse.

Sound wave generation diagram. A vibrating string moves to the right, compressing the air in front of it to create a region of compression and expanding the air behind it to create a region of rarefaction. These alternating compressions and rarefactions propagate through the air as a longitudinal sound wave, illustrating how mechanical vibrations in a source produce sound.

Sound wave formation from a vibrating string. As the string moves to the left, it pushes air particles together on one side, creating a region of compression, while particles on the opposite side move apart, forming a region of rarefaction. The alternating compressions and rarefactions propagate outward through the air as a longitudinal sound wave, demonstrating how oscillating motion of a source generates sound.

Sound wave produced by a vibrating string. Alternating regions of compression and rarefaction propagate outward through the air after repeated vibrations of the source. The lower graph shows gauge pressure versus distance x, oscillating above and below zero, where zero represents atmospheric pressure. Positive pressure corresponds to compressions and negative pressure corresponds to rarefactions, illustrating that sound waves consist of small pressure variations around atmospheric pressure.

Sound waves entering the ear. Alternating compressions and rarefactions travel up the ear canal and strike the eardrum. Changes in air pressure exert a force on the eardrum, given by F = P·A, causing it to vibrate. These vibrations are transmitted through the middle and inner ear and converted into nerve signals that the brain interprets as sound.

Sound wave propagation from a vibrating source. A tuning fork oscillating at frequency f produces alternating compressions and rarefactions that travel outward symmetrically in all directions at wave speed v_w. The spacing between successive compressions defines the wavelength λ. The diagram illustrates the fundamental wave relationship between speed, frequency, and wavelength, emphasizing that in a given medium the speed of sound is approximately independent of frequency.

Graphs comparing sound waves of different intensities. Both graphs show gauge pressure P_g versus position x. The top graph represents a low-intensity sound with small pressure variations around zero, produced by a source with small-amplitude vibrations. The bottom graph represents a high-intensity sound with much larger pressure maxima and minima, produced by larger-amplitude vibrations. The diagram illustrates that greater sound intensity corresponds to larger pressure variations and stronger forces on objects the sound encounters.

Anatomy of the human ear showing the outer, middle, and inner ear. The outer ear includes the pinna and ear canal, which collect and direct sound waves to the eardrum. The middle ear contains the eardrum and oval window, where sound pressure is converted into mechanical vibrations and amplified. The inner ear includes the cochlea, cochlear duct, and round window, where vibrations are transformed into nerve signals sent through the cochlear nerve to the brain. The semicircular canals and vestibule are also shown and are responsible for balance, while the Eustachian tube helps equalize pressure.

Inner ear and middle ear anatomy showing how sound is converted into nerve signals. Sound travels through the ear canal and vibrates the eardrum (tympanum), which moves the three middle-ear bones: the hammer (malleus), anvil (incus), and stirrup (stapes). The stapes presses on the oval window, creating pressure waves in the fluid of the cochlea. These waves move the tectorial membrane and bend the cilia in the organ of Corti, stimulating auditory nerves that send signals to the brain. The round window allows fluid movement, and the Eustachian tube helps equalize pressure in the middle ear.

Sound waves radiating from a stationary source. A car emits sound that spreads outward as concentric spherical wavefronts. Observers X and Y, standing at equal distances on opposite sides, receive the sound with the same wavelength and frequency. The diagram illustrates that when the source, observers, and air are all stationary, sound propagates uniformly in all directions.

Sound waves emitted by a moving source illustrating the Doppler effect. A car moving to the right emits sound waves that spread out from successive positions labeled 1 through 5. Wavefronts are compressed in front of the car toward observer Y, producing a shorter wavelength and higher observed frequency, and spread out behind the car toward observer X, producing a longer wavelength and lower observed frequency. The diagram shows how motion of the source changes the observed sound depending on the observer’s position.

Sound waves from a stationary source illustrating the Doppler effect due to moving observers. A car emits sound waves that spread out uniformly as concentric circles. Observer Y moves toward the source and encounters wave crests more frequently, resulting in a higher observed frequency. Observer X moves away from the source and encounters wave crests less often, resulting in a lower observed frequency. The diagram shows that relative motion between the observer and the source changes the observed frequency even when the source is stationary.

Resonance illustrated with a paddle ball on a rubber band. The finger moves the support at different driving frequencies. At low frequency and high frequency, the ball oscillates with a small amplitude because energy transfer is inefficient. When the driving frequency matches the natural frequency f₀ of the ball–rubber band system, resonance occurs and the oscillation amplitude increases dramatically to about 2X. The diagram demonstrates that resonance produces maximum response when the driving frequency equals the system’s natural frequency.

Beats produced by wave superposition. Two waves with slightly different frequencies f₁ and f₂ and corresponding wavelengths λ₁ and λ₂ overlap in time. The waves alternate between destructive interference, where their amplitudes partially cancel, and constructive interference, where their amplitudes add. The resulting wave shows a periodic increase and decrease in amplitude over time, illustrating the beat phenomenon caused by the small difference in frequencies.

acoustic resonance in an air column closed at one end. A vibrating tuning fork generates sound waves that travel down the tube, reflect off the closed end, and interfere with incoming waves. At specific frequencies, this interference produces standing waves in the air column, leading to resonance where the sound amplitude is significantly increased.

a sound wave traveling through an air-filled tube that is closed at one end. A tuning fork at the open end generates a pressure disturbance that moves into the tube, then reflects off the closed end and travels back toward the opening. This reflection sets up conditions for standing waves and resonance in the air column, a key concept in acoustics and wave behavior in closed tubes.

resonance in an air-filled tube closed at one end, where a tuning fork produces a sound wave that travels into the tube and reflects from the closed end; when the tube length is such that the reflected wave returns half a cycle later, it interferes constructively with the incoming wave to form a standing wave with an antinode at the open end and a node at the closed end, demonstrating resonance in closed air columns studied in acoustics and wave physics.

a standing-wave resonance in a tube closed at one end, where vibrations introduced near the closed end produce a standing wave with zero air displacement at the closed end and maximum displacement at the open end; the figure highlights that the tube length corresponds to odd multiples of one-quarter wavelength, illustrating higher resonant modes and harmonics in closed air columns studied in acoustics and wave physics.

the first overtone resonance in a tube closed at one end, where air displacement is zero at the closed end and maximum at the open end; the standing wave fits three-quarters of a wavelength within the tube length, producing a higher-frequency resonance characteristic of closed-pipe acoustics.

the fundamental mode and first three overtones for a tube closed at one end, where air displacement is zero at the closed end and maximum at the open end; each resonance fits an odd multiple of one quarter wavelength into the tube length L, with increasing frequency and decreasing wavelength for higher overtones, illustrating the harmonic structure of closed-pipe sound waves.

the fundamental mode and first three overtones for a tube open at both ends, where air displacement is maximum at both ends and nodes form inside the tube; each resonant mode fits an integer number of half wavelengths into the tube length L, producing harmonics with wavelengths decreasing and frequencies increasing proportionally with mode number.

an electromagnetic wave showing oscillating electric field (E) and magnetic field (B) vectors that are perpendicular to each other and to the direction of propagation, with both fields in phase and traveling at speed c away from an oscillating charge.

"the electromagnetic spectrum used in physics education to show the full range of electromagnetic radiation organized by wavelength and frequency. The spectrum progresses from radio waves and microwaves with long wavelengths and low frequencies to infrared
column9: and gamma rays with shorter wavelengths and higher frequencies. The diagram highlights that all electromagnetic waves travel at the speed of light but differ in energy
column10: with energy increasing as wavelength decreases and frequency increases."

Modified-Alt-Text: the visible portion of the electromagnetic spectrum showing how visible light fits between infrared and ultraviolet radiation. The visible spectrum is labeled by color from red to violet, with wavelengths decreasing from about 700 nm for red light to about 400 nm for violet light. The diagram illustrates that color is determined by wavelength, with longer wavelengths corresponding to red light and shorter wavelengths corresponding to violet light, and highlights that the boundaries between infrared, visible light, and ultraviolet are gradual rather than sharply defined.

Side-by-side diagrams comparing subtractive and additive color mixing. On the left, the subtractive color model for pigments shows cyan, magenta, and yellow overlapping to form darker colors, with all three combining to produce black due to absorption of light. On the right, the additive color model for light shows red, green, and blue overlapping to create brighter colors, with all three combining to produce white light, illustrating the fundamental difference between pigment mixing and light mixing.

Comparison of visible wavelength ranges perceived by humans, bees, and dogs along a wavelength axis from about 300 to 700 nanometers. Humans perceive visible light from roughly violet to red, bees can see ultraviolet light in addition to part of the visible spectrum but not red, and dogs perceive a narrower range of colors with reduced sensitivity to reds and greens. The figure illustrates that different species experience color differently because their eyes contain different types and numbers of photoreceptor cells.

thin-film interference in optics. An incident light ray strikes the top surface of a thin film with refractive index n2 between two media n1 and n3. Part of the light reflects immediately at the top surface (ray 1), while the rest refracts into the film, reflects off the bottom surface, and exits as ray 2. The two reflected rays travel different optical path lengths, causing constructive or destructive interference depending on the film thickness t, wavelength of light, and refractive indices. This phenomenon explains effects such as color patterns in soap bubbles and the reduction of glare by polarized sunglasses.

polarization of transverse waves using a rope analogy. In panel (a), the rope oscillates in a vertical plane, representing vertically polarized waves that can pass through a vertical slit. In panel (b), the rope oscillates in a horizontal plane, representing horizontally polarized waves that are blocked by a vertical slit. The diagram illustrates that polarization describes the direction of oscillation perpendicular to the direction of wave travel, and that filters or slits only transmit waves polarized in the same direction, a principle that also applies to light waves.

the inverse square law for electromagnetic radiation. A point source emits light that spreads outward uniformly, forming larger spherical surfaces as the distance from the source increases. At distances r, 2r, and 3r, the same amount of radiant energy is distributed over increasingly larger surface areas, causing the intensity or illuminance to decrease with distance. The diagram shows that as the radius of the spherical surface increases, the energy per unit area decreases proportionally to one over the distance squared, explaining why light appears dimmer the farther it travels from its source.

the ways light travels from a source to an observer. Light from the Sun travels through empty space to reach Earth and then continues through different media such as air and glass. In the scene, sunlight enters a window, where it partially transmits through the glass and partially reflects off surfaces before reaching a person’s eyes. The dashed and solid arrows represent straight-line paths of light rays, emphasizing that light propagates in straight lines unless it reflects or changes direction when moving between different materials.

illustrating the law of reflection. An incident light ray strikes a flat surface and reflects away symmetrically on the opposite side of a dashed line that represents the normal, which is perpendicular to the surface. The angle of incidence (θᵢ) is measured between the incoming ray and the normal, and the angle of reflection (θᵣ) is measured between the reflected ray and the normal. The diagram shows that these two angles are equal, demonstrating that light reflects so that the incident ray, reflected ray, and the normal all lie in the same plane.

Diffuse reflection from a rough surface. Several parallel light rays strike an uneven surface, where each small section has a different orientation. As a result, the incoming rays are reflected in many different directions rather than one single direction. This contrasts with reflection from a smooth surface, where rays reflect uniformly. Diffuse reflection explains why rough objects are visible from many viewing angles but do not form clear mirror-like images.

image formation by a flat mirror. Light rays from a bottle reflect off the flat mirror and enter the observer’s eye, obeying the law of reflection where the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection. The reflected rays diverge, but when traced backward as dashed lines, they appear to originate from a point behind the mirror, forming a virtual image. The diagram shows that the image distance di behind the mirror is equal to the object distance do in front of the mirror, explaining why flat mirrors produce upright images that appear the same size as the object but cannot be projected onto a screen.

Comparison of concave and convex mirrors and their focal lengths. In the concave mirror (left), parallel incoming light rays reflect and converge at a focal point F located in front of the mirror, giving the mirror a positive focal length f. This converging behavior allows concave mirrors to form real or virtual images depending on the object’s position relative to the focal point. In the convex mirror (right), parallel rays reflect and diverge outward, appearing to originate from a focal point F located behind the mirror, which is indicated as a negative focal length. Convex mirrors always form virtual, upright, and reduced images because reflected rays never actually meet in front of the mirror.

Image formation for concave and convex mirrors. In (a), an object placed outside the focal point of a concave mirror reflects rays that converge in front of the mirror, forming a real, inverted image on the same side as the object. In (b), when the object is inside the focal point of a concave mirror, the reflected rays diverge and appear to originate from behind the mirror, producing a virtual, upright, and magnified image. In (c), a convex mirror reflects rays that always diverge, regardless of object position, so the image is always virtual, upright, and reduced, appearing behind the mirror.

a Schmidt–Cassegrain telescope illustrating how incoming parallel light from a distant object enters the telescope, reflects off the large concave primary mirror, then reflects from a smaller convex secondary mirror before being brought to focus at the focal plane near the observer’s eye. This folded optical path allows the telescope to have a long effective focal length while remaining physically compact. The design improves light-gathering power and image clarity, making it widely used in astronomical observations to view faint and distant objects such as planets, stars, and galaxies.

a car headlight or spotlight uses a parabolic mirror to control light direction. The bulb is placed at the focal point of the parabolic mirror, so light rays emitted in all directions reflect off the mirror and emerge as parallel rays. This produces a bright, focused beam that travels long distances without spreading out significantly. The same physical principle is used in solar collectors, where sunlight is reflected and concentrated at a focal point to produce heat for energy generation, demonstrating how mirror geometry controls light propagation and energy concentration.

Ray diagram illustrating image formation by a concave mirror and the variables used in mirror and lens calculations. The object is placed at a distance do from the mirror with height ho, while the image forms at distance di with height hi. Rays are drawn using standard construction rules: one ray travels parallel to the principal axis and reflects through the focal point F, another passes through the focal point and reflects parallel to the axis, and a third reflects symmetrically about the normal. These rays intersect to locate the image position and size. The focal length f characterizes the mirror’s curvature and determines how strongly it converges light. The relationships among do, di, and f are described by the mirror (lens) equation, which is used to predict image location and magnification in optical systems such as mirrors, lenses, telescopes, and cameras.

refraction at the boundary between water and air using a fish tank example. Light rays emitted from the fish bend as they pass from water into air because the speed of light changes between the two media. As a result, the rays follow different paths to the observer’s eye, making the fish appear to be in a different position than its true location. This apparent shift occurs because the brain assumes light travels in straight lines and traces the refracted rays backward into the water. Refraction depends on the indices of refraction of the two media and is governed by Snell’s law. This effect explains common optical illusions such as objects appearing closer or displaced in water and is important in applications like lenses, eyeglasses, microscopes, and underwater viewing.

a lawnmower analogy to explain refraction and Snell’s law. The image compares the behavior of a light ray crossing a boundary between two media with different refractive indices to a lawnmower moving from a sidewalk onto grass. In medium 1 (sidewalk), the mower moves faster, just as light travels faster in a medium with a lower refractive index. When the mower enters the grass (medium 2), one wheel slows down first, causing the mower to turn toward the perpendicular; similarly, when light enters a medium where it travels more slowly, it bends toward the normal. In the reverse situation, when moving from grass to sidewalk, the mower speeds up and turns away from the perpendicular, just as light bends away from the normal when it enters a faster medium. This analogy helps visualize how changes in wave speed cause refraction at a boundary and why the angle of refraction depends on the properties of the two media.

refraction and dispersion of light by a glass prism. In panel (a), a single wavelength (pure λ) enters the prism and bends at each glass–air boundary due to the change in speed of light inside the glass. Because only one wavelength is present, the light emerges as a single ray with a new direction. In panel (b), white light enters the prism and is separated into its component colors. This occurs because the index of refraction of glass depends on wavelength, so different colors travel at different speeds inside the prism and bend by different amounts. Shorter wavelengths (violet, around 380 nm) experience a larger refractive index and bend more, while longer wavelengths (red, around 760 nm) bend less. This wavelength-dependent bending is called dispersion and explains phenomena such as rainbows and the separation of colors in optical instruments.

Demonstration of how a rainbow is formed by sunlight interacting with a water droplet. Incoming sunlight enters the droplet and slows down, causing refraction at the air–water boundary. Because the index of refraction of water depends on wavelength, different colors bend by different amounts, with violet bending more than red. After entering the droplet, part of the light reflects off the inner back surface of the droplet. The reflected light then exits the droplet and is refracted a second time as it returns to air, increasing the separation of colors. As a result, red light exits at a larger angle relative to the incoming sunlight, while violet light exits at a smaller angle. When many droplets are present in the atmosphere, each droplet sends a specific color toward the observer, producing the circular arc of colors known as a rainbow.

refraction, the critical angle, and total internal reflection at the boundary between two media with different indices of refraction. In panel (a), a light ray travels from a medium with higher index of refraction (n1) into a medium with lower index of refraction (n2). Because light speeds up when entering the lower-index medium, the refracted ray bends away from the normal (the perpendicular to the surface). The angles of incidence and refraction are measured relative to this normal. In panel (b), the incident angle is increased until the refracted ray travels exactly along the boundary between the two media. This incident angle is called the critical angle, and at this angle the refracted angle is 90 degrees. In panel (c), the incident angle is greater than the critical angle, so refraction no longer occurs. Instead, all the light is reflected back into the original medium, a phenomenon known as total internal reflection. This effect is explained by Snell’s law and is the physical principle behind technologies such as fiber-optic cables and light guides.

Demonstration of how total internal reflection causes diamonds to sparkle. Light entering the diamond from air slows down and bends toward the normal because diamond has a much higher index of refraction than air. When the light reaches an internal surface of the diamond at an angle greater than the critical angle, it cannot refract out into the air. Instead, it undergoes total internal reflection and is reflected entirely back into the diamond. Because the critical angle for a diamond–air boundary is very small, most light rays striking the internal faces are totally reflected multiple times. Diamond facets are carefully cut so that these internally reflected rays are directed back out through the top of the diamond toward the observer. This trapping and controlled release of light increases brightness, intensity, and sparkle, which is why diamonds appear exceptionally brilliant compared to other gemstones.

binoculars use prisms and total internal reflection to redirect light toward the observer’s eyes. Light rays entering the binoculars travel into glass prisms, where they strike internal surfaces at angles greater than the critical angle. Instead of refracting out of the prism, the light undergoes total internal reflection, allowing it to be reflected efficiently without the energy loss that occurs with metallic mirrors. The prisms are arranged as corner reflectors, which reverse and reorient the image so it appears upright and correctly oriented to the viewer. This optical path also allows binoculars to be compact while maintaining a long effective light path for magnification. The same physical principle is used in fiber-optic cables, where light is guided through glass or plastic fibers by repeated total internal reflection, enabling high-speed transmission of data for internet, telephone, and cable television systems.

optical fibers guide light using total internal reflection. Each fiber consists of a central core with a higher index of refraction (n₁) surrounded by cladding with a lower index of refraction (n₂). When light enters the core at a suitable angle, it strikes the core–cladding boundary at angles greater than the critical angle, causing total internal reflection rather than refraction out of the fiber. As a result, the light is confined within the core and can travel long distances with very little loss. Even when the fiber bends, the light continues to reflect internally and follows the curved path, allowing signals to propagate around corners. This principle enables fiber-optic communication systems, which transmit data as pulses of light for internet, telephone, and cable networks, offering high bandwidth, low signal loss, and immunity to electrical interference.

a convex (converging) lens bends light rays and brings them to a focal point. Light rays that enter the lens parallel to the principal axis are refracted at both curved surfaces of the lens and converge at a single point called the focal point (F). The distance from the center of the lens to this focal point is the focal length (f), which is a key property of the lens and determines how strongly it bends light. Ray 2 travels along the axis and passes straight through the lens with minimal deviation, while rays 1 and 3 bend toward the axis due to refraction. The enlarged view on the right shows how refraction occurs at each surface according to Snell’s law, with different angles of incidence and refraction as the light enters and exits the lens. This behavior explains how convex lenses are used in devices such as cameras, microscopes, glasses for farsightedness, and the human eye to focus light and form clear images.

a concave (diverging) lens affects incoming light rays. Rays that enter the lens parallel to the principal axis spread outward after passing through the lens instead of converging. Because the rays diverge, they appear to originate from a focal point (F) located on the same side of the lens as the incoming light. For this reason, the focal length f is defined as negative for a diverging lens. Ray 2 travels along the axis and passes through the center of the lens with minimal bending, while rays 1 and 3 bend away from the axis due to refraction at both lens surfaces. The dashed lines indicate the apparent paths of the rays, not the actual light paths, and are used to locate the virtual focal point. The enlarged view illustrates how Snell’s law governs the change in direction at each surface, with different angles of incidence and refraction. Concave lenses are commonly used in applications such as glasses for nearsightedness, where they spread incoming light so that images focus correctly on the retina.

a converging convex lens showing how a real image is formed. Three light rays originate from the top of an object. Ray 1 travels parallel to the principal axis and refracts through the focal point on the far side of the lens. Ray 2 passes through the center of the lens and continues in a straight line without bending. Ray 3 travels through the focal point on the object side of the lens and emerges parallel to the axis after refraction. The refracted rays intersect on the opposite side of the lens, forming a real inverted image. The diagram labels object distance (do), image distance (di), focal length (f), object height (ho), and image height (hi), illustrating how lens geometry determines image location and magnification.

This is a two part diagram. In part (a), a Galilean telescope uses a convex objective lens and a concave eyepiece. Incoming parallel rays from a distant object enter the objective lens and begin to converge. Before the rays reach a real focus, they pass through the concave eyepiece, which causes the rays to emerge parallel again toward the eye. The final image is upright, virtual, and viewed at infinity, making this design suitable for spyglasses. In part (b), a simple astronomical telescope uses two convex lenses. Light from a very distant object enters the convex objective lens and forms a real, inverted intermediate image of height (hi) at the focal plane of the objective, labeled by the focal length (fo). This intermediate image acts as the object for the eyepiece. The eyepiece, with focal length (fe), produces a magnified virtual final image that is viewed by the eye. Angular directions before and after the eyepiece are indicated by (theta) and (theta prime), showing how the telescope increases angular magnification. The positions of focal points (Fo), (Fe), and (Fe prime) are labeled to show the optical alignment of the system.

a compound microscope consisting of two lenses: an objective lens and an eyepiece. A small object of height (ho) is placed just beyond the focal point (Fo) of the objective lens at a distance (do). Rays from the object pass through the objective lens and form a real, inverted, and magnified first image of height (hi) at a distance (di). This first image lies near the focal point (Fe) of the eyepiece and serves as the object for the eyepiece lens. The eyepiece acts as a magnifying glass and produces a final virtual image of height (hi prime), which is magnified even further and viewed by the eye. The dashed backward extensions of the rays indicate the apparent position of the final image on the same side of the eyepiece as the object. Distances between lenses and images, including (do), (di), and (di prime), are labeled along the optical axis. The diagram emphasizes idealized ray behavior, while noting that real lenses introduce aberrations, which are distortions that cause images to deviate from the predictions of thin-lens ray diagrams.

This is a two part diagram of chromatic aberration and its correction in lens systems. In part (a), white light rays pass through a single convex lens and are separated into different colors due to the wavelength dependence of the lens’s index of refraction. Violet light (V) is bent more strongly than red light (R), causing violet rays to focus closer to the lens and red rays to focus farther away. As a result, the image formed from white light appears spread out with different colors focusing at different positions, producing color fringes and changes in magnification. In part (b), a multiple-lens system is shown reducing chromatic aberration. White light rays pass through a combination of lenses made from different materials or shapes, causing the different colors to refract in a way that brings them closer to a common focus. This partial correction reduces color separation in the final image. The diagram highlights that while chromatic aberration can be mitigated using compound lenses, such systems increase the complexity and cost of optical devices such as cameras and microscopes.

the human eye and how images are formed on the retina. Light enters the eye through the cornea, which provides a large portion of the eye’s refractive power, and then passes through the aqueous humor to the adjustable lens. The lens changes shape to focus light from objects at different distances, allowing a sharp real image to form on the retina. Behind the lens, light travels through the vitreous humor before reaching the retina. The retina contains light-sensitive receptors, with the highest concentration located at the fovea, which is responsible for sharp central vision. The optic nerve exits the eye at the optic disc, creating a blind spot where no receptors are present. Other labeled structures include the iris, which controls the amount of light entering the eye, the ciliary fibers, which adjust the lens shape, and the sclera, which forms the protective outer layer of the eye. The diagram emphasizes the importance of refractive indices in image formation, particularly the large change in refractive index at the cornea–air interface, which plays a key role in focusing light onto the retina.

image formation in the human eye using ray tracing. Light rays from the top and bottom of an object enter the eye and are refracted first at the cornea, where the greatest bending occurs, and again as they pass into and out of the lens. These rays converge to form a real, inverted image on the retina. Rays labeled (1) and (2) originate from one point on the object, while rays (3) and (4) originate from another point, demonstrating how different points on the object map to corresponding points on the retinal image. The diagram shows that the image distance (di) must equal the fixed distance from the lens to the retina in order for the image to be sharply focused. Because the lens-to-retina distance does not change, the eye achieves clear vision by adjusting the focal length of the lens rather than moving the retina. The object distance is drawn smaller than scale to emphasize the focusing behavior rather than the true geometry of the eye.

This is a two part diagram of the comparison of common vision defects in the human eye. In part (a), myopia, or nearsightedness, is shown. Parallel rays from a distant object enter the eye and are converged too strongly, causing them to come to a focus in front of the retina. By the time the rays reach the retina, they are diverging, which results in a blurred image. This effect can occur if the eye’s lens is too strong, meaning it has a focal length that is too short, or if the eye itself is too long from front to back. In part (b), hyperopia, or farsightedness, is illustrated. Rays from a nearby object enter the eye but are not converged enough by the cornea and lens before reaching the retina. As a result, the rays would focus at a point behind the retina, producing blurred vision for close objects. This condition can occur if the lens is too weak, meaning its focal length is too long, or if the eye is too short.

This is a two-part diagram. In part (a), correction of nearsightedness is illustrated. Parallel rays from a distant object first pass through a diverging corrective lens placed in front of the eye. This lens spreads the rays slightly before they enter the eye, compensating for the eye’s overconvergence. As a result, the rays are focused precisely on the retina, allowing the distant object to be seen clearly. The diverging lens forms a virtual image closer to the eye than the original object.In part (b), correction of farsightedness is shown. Rays from a close object pass through a converging corrective lens before entering the eye. The converging lens bends the rays inward, compensating for the eye’s underconvergence. This causes the rays to focus on the retina rather than behind it, producing a clear image of nearby objects. In this case, the converging lens forms a virtual image farther from the eye than the actual object.

image formation by a converging lens. A light bulb is placed at an object distance (do) of 0.75 meters (m) from a lens with focal length (f) of 0.50 meters (m). The focal point (F) is marked on the object side of the lens. Light rays from the bulb pass through the lens and converge on the opposite side, forming a real image on a screen located at an image distance (di) of 1.50 m. One ray travels parallel to the optical axis and refracts through the focal point after passing through the lens, while another ray passes through the center of the lens without bending. The intersection of these rays determines the position and size of the real image on the screen, demonstrating how ray tracing predicts image location and magnification.

refraction of a light ray as it passes through multiple layers of materials with different refractive indices. A ray enters the first medium with refractive index (n1) at an incident angle (theta1), measured from the normal to the surface. Upon crossing into the second medium with refractive index (n2), the ray bends and travels at a refracted angle (theta2), demonstrating how a change in refractive index alters the ray’s direction according to Snell’s law.The ray then enters a third medium with refractive index (n3), where it refracts again and travels at an angle (theta3). Dashed lines show the continuation of the ray if no refraction had occurred, highlighting the bending at each boundary. The horizontal displacement between the actual ray path and the dashed reference path is labeled (delta x), indicating the lateral shift caused by refraction through layered media. The diagram emphasizes how changes in refractive index affect both ray direction and lateral position.

refraction and apparent depth for an object viewed across an air–water boundary. A light source is located underwater at a depth (d) of 2.0 meters (m) below the water surface. Light rays emitted from the source travel upward through the water and refract at the water–air interface. After refraction, the rays bend away from the normal as they enter air and travel toward an observer standing at the edge of a platform 2.0 meters (m) horizontally from the refraction point. Dashed lines show the backward extensions of the refracted rays, indicating the apparent position of the underwater object as seen by the observer. Because of refraction, the object appears shallower than its actual depth. The diagram highlights how the change in refractive index between water and air alters ray paths and causes the apparent location of the light source to differ from its true position.

This is a two part diagram of the comparison of ray-like and wave-like behavior of light. In part (a), a powerful laser at the Paranal Observatory emits a narrow beam that travels in a straight line through the night sky, appearing as a single well-defined ray directed upward toward the Milky Way. This image illustrates how light can be modeled as rays when describing straight-line propagation over long distances. In part (b), a laser beam passes through a grid of closely spaced vertical slits and produces a pattern of bright and dark spots on a screen. This interference pattern results from overlapping light waves that constructively and destructively interfere, demonstrating the wave nature of light. Together, the two images show that light exhibits both ray-like behavior in propagation and wave-like behavior through interference.

Huygens’ principle applied to a straight wavefront. An initial straight wavefront, labeled as the old wavefront, is shown as a vertical line. Each point along this wavefront acts as a source of a semicircular wavelet that propagates forward with speed (v). After a time interval (t), each wavelet has advanced a distance (s), where (s = v t). The new wavefront is constructed by drawing a line tangent to the advancing wavelets, forming another straight line parallel to the original wavefront. An arrow indicates the direction of wave propagation, perpendicular to the wavefronts. The diagram demonstrates how uniform forward motion of a wave can be understood as the combined effect of many secondary wavelets, providing the basis for explaining reflection, refraction, and diffraction of waves.

diffraction using Huygens’ principle. A straight wavefront approaches an opening in a barrier and passes through the gap. After passing through the opening, the wavefront no longer remains straight. Instead, the edges of the wavefront bend outward and spread into the region beyond the opening. This bending of waves around the edges of an opening is called diffraction. This shows that when the opening is relatively wide, the wavefront spreads only slightly and continues mostly in its original direction. When the opening is narrow, comparable in size to the wavelength, the wave spreads out more strongly and forms curved wavefronts. Arrows indicate the direction of wave propagation before and after the opening. The figure demonstrates that diffraction effects become more pronounced when the size of the opening is similar to the wavelength of the wave, a behavior commonly observed in water waves, sound waves, and light.

Young’s double-slit experiment. Light of a single wavelength travels toward a barrier containing two narrow, closely spaced vertical slits. After passing through the slits, the light spreads out due to diffraction and the emerging waves overlap. On the screen beyond the slits, this overlap produces a diffraction and interference pattern consisting of many bright and dark vertical fringes that are spread out horizontally. This contrasts this result with the case in which diffraction and interference do not occur. Without these wave effects, the light would form only two bright vertical lines corresponding to the positions of the slits. Instead, each slit acts as a source of semicircular wavefronts, and constructive interference occurs at points where the waves arrive in phase, while destructive interference produces dark regions. This figure demonstrates the wave nature of light through diffraction and interference.

This is a three part diagram of the interference from a double-slit arrangement using wavefronts, water waves, and light. In part (a), plane wavefronts approach a barrier containing two narrow slits labeled (S1) and (S2). Each slit acts as a source of circular wavefronts due to diffraction. As these wavefronts spread outward, they overlap and interfere. On the screen to the right, regions of constructive interference produce intensity maxima, labeled “Max,” while regions of destructive interference produce minima, labeled “Min.”. In part (b), a pattern formed by water waves passing through two openings is shown. The overlapping circular ripples create a series of alternating regions of strong and weak wave motion, demonstrating constructive and destructive interference similar to that of light. In part (c), a photograph of the light interference pattern produced by a double-slit experiment is shown as a series of bright and dark vertical fringes on a screen. Together, the three panels demonstrate that double slits produce two coherent wave sources whose interference patterns are the same for light and water waves, confirming the wave nature of light.

The geometry of path difference in a double-slit interference experiment. Two narrow slits, labeled (S1) and (S2), are separated by a vertical distance (d). Light from each slit travels to a common point on a distant screen at an angle (theta) measured from the central axis. The two ray paths have lengths (L1) and (L2), which differ by a path difference (delta L). From the geometry of the diagram, the path difference is given by (delta L = d sin theta), assuming that the distance to the screen is much greater than the separation between the slits. This path difference determines whether the light arriving at the screen produces constructive or destructive interference. The figure provides the basis for predicting the positions of bright and dark interference fringes on the screen as a function of angle.

the intensity of a double-slit interference pattern varies with angle and position on a screen.
